awd_titl_txt: A search for novel efficient p-type nitride materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: Gallium nitride (GaN) semiconductor is a key component in bright light-emitting diodes (LEDs) used in solid-state lighting and other electronics applications. Most of these devices rely on so-called p-type GaN, a material with added impurities, which greatly improve its properties. In addition, exciting opportunities in optoelectronics currently emerge in development of a related material, p-type AlGaN.  This is potentially groundbreaking since it will pave the way toward bright ultraviolet (UV) LEDs that can be used in numerous energy efficient applications, including air and water purification, phototherapy, gas sensing, plant growth lighting, and UV curing. The integrated experiment/theory research project is aimed at realizing new efficient conductive p-type GaN and AlGaN semiconductor materials. Adding beryllium (Be) impurity to GaN and AlGaN is expected to result in significantly improved p-type conductivity of these materials, leading to dramatic improvement of UV LED efficiency. Students, including those from underrepresented groups, have the opportunity to gain hands-on experience with state-of-the-art material deposition, optical spectroscopy experiments, and theoretical calculations. The project also builds a strong foundation for research and education in a relatively small Physics Department at Virginia Commonwealth University. 

Technical Description: The project focuses on growth of Be-doped GaN and AlGaN and fundamental studies of point defects in these materials. Analysis of photoluminescence from Be-doped GaN indicates that Be is the shallowest acceptor in GaN, yet achievement of p-type conductivity is still a challenging task, because a variety of point defects are formed during material growth. This collaborative research involves first-principles calculations of microscopic properties of Be and related defects in GaN and AlGaN, growth of Be-doped GaN and AlGaN by metalorganic chemical vapor deposition method, use of ion implantation, thermal annealing, and detailed experimental studies, primarily with photoluminescence and Kelvin probe methods. The roles of growth conditions (temperature, pressure, gas ambient), co-doping with Si and Mg, delta doping techniques, use of surfactants, various thermal annealing approaches are investigated to achieve conductive p-type materials. An in-depth and comprehensive study of the properties and behavior of Be and other defects in GaN and AlGaN by using advanced experimental and theoretical approaches is essential to gain a basic understanding of point defects in semiconductors, the mechanisms of radiative and nonradiative recombination, and possible growth pathways for realizing the efficient p-type materials. Furthermore, the accuracy of current approaches in solid-state theory is critically examined through direct experimental verification.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The realization of high-conductivity p-type gallium nitride (GaN) semiconductor and aluminum-gallium nitride (AlGaN) alloy by doping these materials with novel acceptor impurities is potentially groundbreaking for optoelectronics and power electronics. In optoelectronics, it will pave the way toward bright ultraviolet (UV) light emitting devices (LED) that can be used in numerous energy-efficient applications, including air and water purification, phototherapy, gas sensing, plant growth lighting, and UV curing.  However, up to now, point defects in these semiconductors, that can be beneficial or detrimental, are poorly understood. The central theme of the proposed research was the investigation of beryllium (Be) impurity and related point defects in GaN (point defects are atomic-size defects of the crystal lattice, impurity atoms in specific locations of a crystal, and complex defects consisting of two or more simple defects). Preliminary results showed that Be doping introduces the shallowest acceptor level in GaN; i.e., it could be the best dopant for conductive p-type GaN. We also expected that Be could be the best acceptor dopant in AlGaN, the material best suited for the new generation of bright UV LEDs.

This four-year project used the synergy between theory (Demchenko, VCU), experiment (Reshchikov, VCU), and fabrication (Shahedipour-Sandvik, SUNY-Albany). Our team at SUNY-Albany pioneered the growth of high-quality Be-doped GaN layers by metalorganic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) - the most advanced and practical method for nitride-based semiconductor technology. State-of-the-art theoretical calculations predicted properties of point defects that were compared with the experiment. This project resulted in a deep understanding of the beryllium in gallium site (BeGa) acceptor in GaN. From extensive photoluminescence (PL) studies three -/0 transition levels of this acceptor were found: at 0.20, 0.30, and 0.34 eV above the valence band. Although these levels are slightly deeper than the -/0 level of the magnesium (MgGa) acceptor, doping of GaN and AlGaN with Be remains promising for novel conductive p-type materials that will improve the efficiency of blue and UV LEDs. Another shallow Be-related acceptor in GaN, with an ionization energy of 0.113 eV was also studied in detail, yet its chemical origin and structure remains undetermined.

Overall, the project provided substantial educational and training opportunities for two graduate students who are expected to graduate with a Ph.D. degree in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology at VCU and 1 graduate student at SUNY-Albany with a Ph.D. degree in Nanoscale Engineering. The work under this grant, despite interruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, was very productive. It resulted in one book chapter and 20 refereed journal articles in prestigious physics journals such as Physical Review Letters, Physical Review B, Physica Status Solidi, and Journal of Applied Physics. The results were reported at 6 conferences, including International Conference on Defects in Semiconductors, International Workshop on Nitride Semiconductors, SPIE Photonics West, and others (11 presentations, including 4 invited talks).

Within this project, we developed a close collaboration with Prof. Bockowski at the Institute of High-Pressure Physics in Warsaw, Poland. Their research group is acknowledged world leader in the growth of undoped and doped GaN crystals by ammonothermal and high-pressure techniques, and also in annealing of grown crystals at high temperatures and ultrahigh nitrogen pressure. Jointly, we explored opportunities to implant Be into GaN and anneal the implanted samples in various conditions to achieve the high optical quality of the material. This collaboration resulted in four publications.

The project has built a strong collaboration between researchers at VCU and SUNY-Albany. It was a unique opportunity for students in the two universities to simultaneously explore material science, experimental and theoretical approaches in solid state physics, and learn the physics of defects in semiconductors.
